characters: -- SKULL MISSING ENTIRE FRONTAL PLANE FROM BLUNT FORCE TR
-- FLAKES OF OAK BARK ON BLOOD-SPATTERED SHEETS
THIS BARRAGE OF IMAGES ALL CULMINATES WITH ONE WORD SCRAW
IN THE DUST OF THE WINDOW AS LIZ REMOVES THE PHOTO...
EARLIER MOMENTS FROM OUR MOVIE THAT NOW HAVE A COMPLETELY
DIFFERENT FEEL TO THEM IN THIS NEW CONTEXT...
EXTREMELY WICKED, SHOCKINGLY EVIL, AND VILE
BARRAGE OF IMAGERY THAT IS EXTREMELY WICKED, SHOCKINGLY E

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We’re taken back to... SUPER: 1969. Five Years Earlier The height of innocence and bubblegum pop. It’s ladies ni at a popular college bar. Two frothy beers plunk down on table crowded with empties, where LIZ commiserates with h best friend JOANNA.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Why did you have to drag me to a college bar? I feel invisible here.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: The best way to get over someone is to get under someone.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: No guy wants to go with a single mom who works as a secretary.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Tonight you’re not a single mom, you're single. You’re not a secretary, you have a secretary. And how can you be invisible if that guy’s been staring at you all night? Liz glances across the way at someone who causes her to momentarily lose herself. We don’t see him yet -- we stay her. Because she just fell in love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are my candy girl... And you got me wanting you... Liz looks away. Takes a long pull on her beer.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: He’s not staring at me, he’s staring at the blonde on the dance floor who’s not wearing a bra.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: I think he’s coming over.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I think if I hear one more love song I’m going to puke. Liz gets up. Stumbles. She’s had a few. On her way to the jukebox, she fumbles coins from her pocket which roll awa As she curses to herself and crouches to find them, TWO F step up. The stranger opens his palm revealing a single coin. Liz rises to meet TED. Handsome. Dapper. A smile that turns strangers into friends. She has yet to look away fr his beautiful blue eyes. We have too. He has a clean cut, preppy look compared to all the longhairs.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s my last dime so we better make it a good one. In the background, Joanna checks out his ass. Gives Liz emphatic approval. Liz can’t find her voice.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I haven’t seen you here before.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: It’s the first time I’ve been out since I moved to Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Explains the new car smell.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: No, that’s just Utah.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That’s in Wyoming, right? Liz hides a smile. They flip through the selection cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you do? Work? School? Race car driver? Liz glances at Joanna in the background. Tries out her li

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I make heart valves.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m a lawyer. Ever hear of voir dire?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Is that Latin or are you slurring too? Ted bashfully laughs -- one of his endearing qualities.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Is it that obvious?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: So what are you going to play for me, counselor? He pretends like he’s studying her.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Given it’s taken you this long to leave your seat, I’d say you’re probably ready to move. Since you needed four beers to get there, I suspect you’re usually too shy to dance. But you left it up to me, so you're willing to take a risk. And seeing as you spent the entire night crying to your girlfriend instead of noticing me noticing you, I’m guessing probably not a love song. Unless you’re feeling hopeful? This guy’s good.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: How are you feeling? Ted inserts the coin. Punches a number.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Like we could both use some company. The opening pep of “Build Me Up Buttercup” by the Founda rile up the place. Liz wilts in shyness. Ted pulls her toward the dance floor.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What’s the matter? They don’t have dancing in Utah? What do they call folks from Utah anyway? Utonians? Utahites? Utahcrats? Liz considers him. His eyes. His ease. His ear-to-ear gri that’s as goofy as it is charming. There’s something abou him that’s magnetic. Liz downs the rest of her beer.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (hick voice) Utaaaaaaahns. They laugh and start dancing with complete and utter reck abandon. With the complete innocence of youth.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUNDATIONS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why do you build me up...? Buttercup, baby, just to let me down... And mess me around... And then worst of all... After a while, Ted pulls Liz close. Feels more intimate:

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What do you say we get outta here?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I don’t even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: But you already feel like you've known me all your life.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Because I feel the same. The electricity is undeniable. Each sizzling with desire, leans in to kiss her...

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Wait. I don’t make heart valves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) I’m not a lawyer. Then, as if the world disappears around them, they kiss.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUNDATIONS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Buttercup, don't break my heart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stumble out laughing, heading for Liz's car.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m applying to law school after I graduate -- if I ever finish my Chinese Studies major, that is.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Does that mean you speak Chinese?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Wo zai sho-hua.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: What did you just say? Ted shrugs. They both laugh. Liz, clearly the drunker one misses the keyhole on her car.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (John Wayne impression) Now, listen here, pilgrim. A cowboy never lets a lassie drive drunk. Life is hard, but it’s harder if you’re stupid, and gettin’ behind that wheel is ri-god- damn-diculous. So hand ‘em here, or I’m gonna hafta frisk ya’. She teasingly hides her keys behind her back so he has to his arms around her to get them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted’s VW BUG pulls over in a nice neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Why are we stopping?

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wanna show you something.  HOLD ON the IDLING ENGINE of Ted’s Bug.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: Ted and Liz stroll arm-in-arm through the upscale neighborhood, brown-bagging a bottle of wine, his coat ar her, comfortably close now.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Someday, when I’m a big-wig lawyer, I’m going to buy one of these houses.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: There’s one I like, it’s big, with a brick chimney, and a view of the Puget Sound, not far from here.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I can see it already -- warm fires on cold Seattle nights, barbeques in the backyard with friends...

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: And a Mercedes in the driveway?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: We should get a dog too! A big one that we can take on hikes with us. In fact, I can hear him barking now. Do you hear it? He makes her listen to the peaceful night breeze -- then BARKS really loud in her ear, scaring her half to death. They laugh and cuddle, the stars infinite and bright abov

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at her front door. Ted waits expectantly but looks hesitant about inviting him in.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Guess I better get going. His disappointment is palpable. Liz is obviously conflict Then the front door OPENS, revealing a HIGH SCHOOL GIRL w her coat and backpack. Liz blushes, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: HIGH SCHOOL GIRL
dialogues.text: Sorry to interrupt, but you said you'd be back two hours ago and I have school tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, this is Rachel. My sitter. (then) I understand if you want to go. Liz braces for rejection like she’s used to it.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Why on earth would I want to do that? Liz sighs with relief. INT. LIZ’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 6 Ted and Liz look in on her BABY, asleep in a crib.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Are you sure you don’t want to run?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Only if it’s after you. She smiles. They lay down on the bed, fully clothed. She puts her head on his chest and closes her eyes. They fall asleep together. Tender, sweet, and innocent. FADE TO BLACK. INT. LIZ’S BEDROOM - DAY 7 Sunlight floods the room. Liz is sprawled out in bed. As she wakes, the night’s events start to come back to her. looks over at the other side of the bed -- it’s empty. And so is the crib. Liz dashes out in a panic--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --as Ted turns around with a knife, chopping omelette veggies, cooing at Liz’s baby in a high chair. An idyllic domestic scene with brilliant morning light saturating everything. He flashes that smile again when he notices L

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You looked so pretty sleeping, I didn’t want to-- She cuts him off with a kiss. This is what love looks lik

dialogues.speaker: BEGIN TITLE SEQUENCE
dialogues.text: A collage of PHOTOS and HOME MOVIES that show the blossom of a spectacular relationship: Two beautiful young lovers a baby that’s growing up... holidays... vacations... birthdays... ticket stubs... a love we all hope for. The images start to come faster, the passage of time show the baby growing into a LITTLE GIRL, faster, faster still

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Volkswagen Bug sputters by dark houses in the pre-dawn hour. SUPER: Utah. Six Years Later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted’s hunched over the wheel, driving the quiet, dark str His hair is longer, shaggier now. In his rearview, he notices another car tailing him, whic can only make as a silhouette behind the headlights. Ted gives it a little gas but the other car keeps pace. Suddenly the high beams flip on. He squints from the reflection in his rearview. Scared now, Ted punches it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Volkswagen Bug accelerates. The pursuing car keeps pa Ted burns through a stop sign. Only then do we realize that the pursuing car is a cop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red and blue lights play over Ted’s face. He curses and steers over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted cuts the engine and gets out. He strolls to the rear his car as the cop pulls in behind. Ted shrugs, flashes t million dollar smile -- now becoming familiar to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepishly) I guess I’m lost. 11. The cop is BOB HAYWARD, a no-nonsense highway patrol vete on the tail end of his shift. Smiles don’t work on him.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HAYWARD
dialogues.text: You ran two stop signs, son.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I do apologize, Officer, but I couldn’t make your car with the headlights in my eyes and, well, I guess I got spooked.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HAYWARD
dialogues.text: Got a license? Ted produces his ID.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HAYWARD
dialogues.text: What’s a kid from Seattle doing in Granger, Utah this time of morning?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I caught a late movie at the Redwood but I obviously missed the interstate on my way home. These subdivisions, man...

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HAYWARD
dialogues.text: Must have been a good movie, drove all the way from Washington.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I live in Salt Lake now. I’ma law student at the University of Utah. Hayward pans his flashlight inside Ted’s car.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (small talk) My girlfriend lives in Seattle. I’m going to propose once I graduate. Right now, I’m just trying to save money for a ring so I'd really appreciate getting off without a ticket, if you can find the heart.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HAYWARD
dialogues.text: What’d you see tonight?  14 15 16 17 12.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: The Towering Inferno. Hayward pans the flashlight back on Ted.

dialogues.speaker: SMASH TO
dialogues.text: HANDCUFFS snap around Ted’s wrists. Hayward shuts Ted in the back of a squad car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted laughs, shaking his head at the absurdity of events a Hayward removes items from a black canvas duffle bag...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s just junk I picked up around the house, I swear. Garbage bags... flashlight... gloves... rope... (NOTE: Additional items need to be shot; see end montage. “POSSESSION OF BURGLARY TOOLS,” reads the arrest report.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER HAYWARD
dialogues.text: Ever been to the town of Murray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and seven doppelgangers file into a lineup facing the own reflections in a two-way mirror. Ted steps forward, turns profile, swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted turns for a mug shot, eyes ringed with shock.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HANSON, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: You are hereby charged with aggravated kidnapping and attempted criminal assault. The flash bulb POPS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stands for arraignment, face drained of color.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HANSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Trial is set for the twenty-third of February. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HANSON, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You shall remain in the custody of the Salt Lake County Sheriff's Department. Bail is set at one hundred thousand dollars. The GAVEL-POUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz types at her desk. A FRAMED PICTURE of her and Ted caught in a moment of uncontrollable laughter beside.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hey Liz, isn’t this your boyfriend? Liz's work neighbor JERRY -- unassuming, kinda shlubby -- leans over to show her a newspaper. What she sees stuns h She starts to feel uncomfortable when she notices coworke looking at her. (She’s the only woman who works here.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's lawyer JOHN O'CONNELL enters in his usual cowboy ha and boots. He’s tall, bearded, with overgrown black hair.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: John, what the hell is going on?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Let’s start on November 8th, 1974.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: If I can’t remember where I was on a random night one year ago, it’s because my memory does not improve with time. It’s safe to say what I was not doing, however. I was not having heart surgery, nor was I taking ballet lessons, nor was I in Mexico, nor was I abducting a complete stranger.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: An alibi would be the best first step.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I don’t even know this woman! My heart goes out to her because that is a truly awful thing for anyone to have gone through, but she’s obviously mistaking me for someone else.  14.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: The good news is there’s no physical evidence and eye witness testimony is precarious at best.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Why is this happening?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: You remember anything about two girls disappearing at a lake last year in Seattle?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (searching) Yeah, I remember a police sketch of the suspect in the paper -- all my friends teased me about a resemblance. No one was serious, though.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Someone must have been because your name landed on a list. When the Utah police got wind of that, they started looking at you with more serious eyes because a similar thing has been happening here.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I have a girlfriend, who has a young daughter, both of whom I love dearly. I would never hurt a woman.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: There are twelve hundred names on that list and last I checked, brown hair and blue eyes are hardly grounds for conviction. It’s an open and shut case, as far as I’m concerned. Let me do what I do best and in the end it’1ll be nothing more than a funny story you tell at cocktail parties. You’re posting tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: My bail’s a hundred grand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: For a boyscout with no priors? I knocked it down to fifteen.  20 21 22 15.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I don’t have fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Your pals in the Washington State governor's office passed a hat around. You think Utah’s top defense attorney works pro bono? Ted smiles. Finally good news.

dialogues.speaker: POURING RAIN, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: INT. KITCHEN - LIZ’S HOUSE - DAY 20 Wine POURS into a glass. Liz anxiously bounces her knee a the table with the newspaper Jerry showed her laid out be her. She takes a big drink. Also at the table, her daughter MOLLY (now 8) draws a pic of a shark with crayons. The DOORBELL RINGS. Before Molly gets up--

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Stay here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz opens the door, revealing Ted holding a newspaper ove his head in the rain. As he takes her face in his hands t kiss her -- she slaps him.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Jesus, Liz! What was that for? Liz shows him the newspaper he was using as an umbrella. He’s mortified by the headline.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: How many stop signs did you run?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We finally see the newspaper: “Seattle Man Arrested in Ut with TED’'S MUGSHOT. Picking up mid-argument:

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You don’t actually believe this garbage, do you? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For chrissakes, Liz, I don’t know if I should be offended or rolling on the floor laughing.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: It’s in all the papers, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That must make it true then. In six years, have I ever laid a hand on you? When we went shopping for ski racks and that lady got her purse snatched, what did I do? What did I do, Liz?!

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: You ran him down.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (re: newspaper) Is that the behavior of a man who does this? Jesus, Liz. You wanna search my bags too? Liz breaks down crying.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (softening) Come here, stupid. Ted pulls her into a hug.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I didn’t tell you because I didn’t want you to freak out. It’s not exactly something to say over the phone. And, honestly, I was embarrassed. It’s all a big misunderstanding. I know it’s hard being apart, but we only have four semesters standing between us and our place on the Sound with a Mercedes and a dog, just like we always dreamed. The moment's interrupted when Molly charges in, excited t see Ted.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Ted!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Monkey! I missed you so much!  23 Ted scoops her up, slings her over his shoulder, her up and down.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Sack o’ potatoes! Sack o’ potatoes! Molly laughs hysterically. It’s their game.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (to Molly) I missed you so much, monkey. What do you say we get cheeseburgers and root beer floats tonight, and be big fatsoes?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Can we go to the Pepper Pod, Mom? Can we, can we, can we?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Yeah, can we, Mommy? Liz considers Ted and Molly. A precious sight.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (reassuring, to Liz) It’s just a big misunderstanding. I’ve got it all under control. Liz finally softens. She believes him.
and bounces 23 Ted and Liz talk over cheeseburgers and fries while Molly colors with crayons on butcher paper.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You can ask me anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Did you do it, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: No, monkey. And I hired the best defense attorney in Utah and he says this case has no legs. It’s all going to be thrown out.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Why did she pick you out of the lineup?  18.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: My lawyer found out the police showed her my picture beforehand -- twice. So of course I looked familiar to her. But that’s not the worst part. What happened in Utah wasn’t dumb luck, Liz. The police already had my name. Someone gave it to them.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (beat) Who would do that to you?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m sure I made a few enemies the year I worked the Rockefeller campaign, but that was politics. This is personal. It doesn’t add up, Liz. The traffic stop, sure -- that was wrong place, wrong time -- but the way it escalated? What the hell are “burglary tools” anyways? There was nothing in my car you wouldn't also find in your own house right now. Only reason it was in there was because I was cleaning up before your visit. Now, suddenly I’m on trial, it’s in all the papers, and my name’s been smeared before I even had a chance to clear it. (looks past her) See that car over there? It’s been following me since I got back. (leans in) I_think I’m being set up. A sense of paranoia builds as Liz turns to look... until she’s startled by--

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Done! Molly shows them a CRAYON SHARK DRAWING she just did.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: It’s a thresher shark. They have a tail as long as their whole body.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: They do?! How did you get so smart, monkey?  24 19.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: I read a lot. Ted tickles Molly, as Liz looks at the DARK SEDAN out the window Ted was referring to. She looks worried for Ted. Over the din of a cocktail reception:

dialogues.speaker: ROSS DAVIS, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Hold on to this one, honey. He’1l be governor himself one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Republican fundraiser. ROSS DAVIS, Chairman of the WA State Republican Party, slings his arm around Ted, boasti to Liz.

dialogues.speaker: ROSS DAVIS
dialogues.text: This man single-handedly got Dan Evans re-elected. Ted secretly rolls his eyes at Liz. He excuses himself to steal away with Liz for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I know how you hate these things so I won’t be completely torn up if you want to leave.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Great. Then you won’t mind if I do?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: These people raised money for your defense!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: And I’m grateful, but c’mon, I’ve had yawns more exciting than this.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: We do need to get the sitter home by ten, but I thought I was dropping you at the law library to get ready for trial?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Welcome home, stranger.  20. They're interrupted by a tall woman in thick, tinted glas who hugs Ted. Pretty in a boyish way, her name is CAROLE BOONE.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Carole Ann! My goodness. How are you? Have you met my girlfriend Liz? (to Liz) Carole Ann and I worked together at DES in Olympia years ago. (to Carole Ann) How's your son?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: He just turned eight.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s my daughter’s age. (joking) Maybe they’1l date.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (excusing himself) Will you excuse us a second, Carole Ann? Ted walks Liz to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: How will you get to the library?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I just squeezed fifteen grand out of the Republican Party, I’m sure I can hitch a ride. He pretends to bite her nose. Liz smiles. Completely in love. As she exits, Ted sees her off... then Carole Ann moseys over next to him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: She seems great.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: She's the best. Liz is my rock.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Everything's going to be okay, you know. The young Republican who worked the suicide prevention hotline? How many lives have you saved, for godsakes? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoever this woman accusing you is, I’m sure she’s just mixing you up with another handsome stranger. There’s an awkward pause. Ted smiles bashfully. Carole An has a noticeable spark in her eye for Ted.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: If you need anything -- anything at all... Ted blushes, registers the roaring sexual tension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted enters the law library. All the girls turn their head one by one, watching him pass. One girl watches him from over her NEWSPAPER. Ted sends them all friendly smiles an winks, loving every second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz brushes her teeth before bed, as her eyes land on TED SUITCASE. She goes to it, thinks for a beat, then looks through clothes, toiletries, check book, etc. Nothing out the ordinary. She smells his clothes. Off her ambiguous look...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted browses legal tomes. An ATTRACTIVE GIRL catches his e through the HORIZONTAL GAP in the bookshelf. They can onl see each other’s EYES. She smiles at him. Ted smiles back. Moments later, she nudges a book from he side, JUTTING OUT the opposing book on Ted’s side. Ted debates, then returns a nudge of his own. They repeat this exchange, a flirtation like PIANO KEYS d the shelf, until they get to the end where there are no m books and they finally see each other’s faces. They’re both startled by a SECURITY GUARD...

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Sir, will you come with me please? ANGLE ON -- the girl reading the newspaper, watching Ted escorted out, as the camera lands on TED’S MUGSHOT.  29 30 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted protests as he’s escorted out.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I am an alumnus of this school!

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Look, buddy, you seem like a nice guy, but you’re making the girls nervous.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What do they think I’m going to do, knock ‘em over the head and attack ‘em in the bookstacks? The guard shuts the door on Ted. Fuming, Ted spots a SIMI DARK SEDAN across the street. The same one, or different? We can’t tell. He marches up to it. Bangs on the window.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Hey! Who are you? I know you’re following me! The car starts up and drives away.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Who sent you?! As it speeds off into the darkness, Ted fills with anger. Paranoia. Fear. He stands in the quiet night... alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead of night. Liz is fast asleep. She stirs, squints her eyes open... and realizes SOMEONE’s sitting next to her U

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SHEETS with a LIGHT ON. She screams! Jumps up! Ted startles out from under the sheets. Flashlight in his hand. Surprised by Liz’s reaction.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (re: flashlight) What are you doing? Ted shows her a paperback he’s reading. Astute viewers ma notice it’s Capote’s In Cold Blood.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Reading.  31 23.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: With a flashlight under the sheets?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I didn’t want to wake you. They realize the absurdity of the situation and break int laughter. As Liz starts to catch her breath...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I think we should get married. Liz loses her breath completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two skiers zzzzZZZZOOOOOOMMMM past in a blur. Ted and Liz cut down a daunting double black diamond. Liz pulls ahead Ted crouches lower. Gains ground. Neck and neck, fast approaching the finish... ...Liz wins by a hair! She taunts him in celebration. He tackles her in the snow and kisses her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Liz meet O’Connell outside the courtroom on their in. Ted’s clean shaven in a light blue/gray suit, white shirt, and bow tie -- and noticeably tanner.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Where'd you fly in from, Barbados?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Liz and I hit the slopes yesterday. We're engaged! Once we win this thing, I might just make you my best man.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (re: O’Connell’s beard) You'll have to shave for our wedding photos, of course. Won't you scare the jury with that thing?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: If we had one. We waived it. Local press all but convicted him so an impartial jury was hard to find.  33 24.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (to Ted) You waived the jury? Shouldn't we have talked about this?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s a good thing, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: The whole case hinges on eyewitness testimony which is notoriously unreliable, but the most likely thing for a jury to convict on.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That's why we’re putting it all in the hands of the judge.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Hanson’s a fair-minded guy with a reputation for controversial acquittals. I went to school with the sonofabitch.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (to O’Connell) You're really going to shave for the wedding?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Blow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE HANSON presides over a high-ceilinged courtroom. No jury in the box. Ted finds Liz in the sparse gallery. Sends her a wink as prosecutor DAVID YOCOM delivers his opening statement.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: Your Honor, November 8th, 1974 may have been just another rainy night for most of Murray, Utah, but it was a life-altering tornado of horror for one woman in particular. She was shopping for a birthday gift at the Fashion Place Shopping Mall when she was approached by a man posing as a police officer. He flashed a badge and asked her to come with him. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As the daughter of a police officer, she felt foolish to question his authority, so she followed him to the parking lot where he led her to what he claimed to be an unmarked police vehicle. When he drove in the opposite direction of the police department, she knew she was in trouble. When he slapped a handcuff around her wrist, she knew she was in danger. Fortunately, before he could latch the other, she twisted free and fled for her life. (beat) Then he pursued her with a crowbar. The courtroom suddenly drops a few degrees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL DARONCH, a soft-featured, 19-year old, strawberry blonde girl, relives the pain of that night.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL DARONCH
dialogues.text: I was kicking him, and screaming. He held a small black gun to my head and said, “If you don’t stop screaming, I’m going to kill you. I'll blow your brains out.” I fell backward out of his car, and I ran as fast as I could.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: As best you recall, Carol, is that man present in court today?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL DARONCH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: Where is he seated? She timidly looks toward Ted, who looks equally sympathet and incredulous. Liz sends him support from the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: Let the record show the identification of the defendant. No further questions, Your Honor. Ted's lawyer JOHN O'CONNELL rises in his usual cowboy hat boots. He’s out for blood.  26.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Ms. DaRonch, it is your testimony now that you did scratch this man?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE DARONCH
dialogues.text: All my fingernails were broken.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Yet in the preliminary hearing Mr. Yocom asked, “Do you recall ever scratching him with those fingernails?” and you answered, “No.” Do you have an explanation for that?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL DARONCH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: In fact, the officers on November 8th asked if you remembered if you hurt the man in any way, and you told them no then too, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL DARONCH
dialogues.text: I don’t remember.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: You also said he had a mustache. But shortly after the incident you said he didn’t. Then sometime later you decided he did again?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL DARONCH
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: When did you make that decision?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL DARONCH
dialogues.text: Right after I decided that he didn’t have one.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Ms. DaRonch, had the police shown you any pictures of the defendant prior to your identification of him at the October 2nd lineup?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL DARONCH
dialogues.text: Yes.  27.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: You did in fact pick his picture out of a pile. But when asked why you chose his picture specifically, you stated, “It looks something like him, but I really couldn't say for sure.” DaRonch looks down. Tears up.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Tell me, Ms. DaRonch. If you were unsure of your identification then, ten months after the incident, what makes you so sure of it now, nearly a_year and a half later? DaRonch is at a complete loss.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: Now Ted’s on the witness stand -- dapper, relaxed, and confident. Liz sends him encouragement from the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: Do you remember the night of August 16th, 1975?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (smiles) Isn’t that why we’re all here? A few laughs in the courtroom. Not even a grin from Yocom

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: You were arrested for fleeing an officer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Objection, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: You were arrested for evading an officer.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Objection.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: How about rabbited?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: Fine. Why did you “rabbit” from Officer Hayward?  28.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: The truth?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: Only that which you swore to tell in whole and nothing but.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (matter-of-factly) I was smoking marijuana. O'Connell nearly leaps out of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Objection! Your Honor, I’d like to request a five minute conference with my cli--

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s okay, John. (to Yocom) I was smoking grass and had to air out the car. I’m only grateful the officer didn’t notice me flick it out the window or he’d have stuck me with littering too and then I'd really be up a creek. Chuckles in the court. 0O’Connell’s about to faint.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: But you withheld this detail from your arresting officer, and apparently even your own attorney.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I was embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID YOCOM
dialogues.text: That may be, sir, but at the end of the day a lie is a lie. Ted sheepishly grins, the gravity of his candor sinking i 35 INT. JOHN O’CONNELL’S OFFICE - DAY 35 O'Connell barges in, followed by Ted and Liz.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Stoned?!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Now, John, let’s just relax here.  29.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Do you realize you just took a dump on our entire defense? The game plan was keep your mouth shut and stick to the script.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I won't sit there like a stuffed shirt while the state distorts all the facts. They’re railroading me!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Your grandstanding took precedence over basic strategy and now it’s all but done you in.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: People respect honesty. I think it was courageous. The truth is always the way to go.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: In court, truth is what you leave out -- especially when it’s a liability.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: It’s going to turn out fine. I know it. I have a feeling.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: It’s in the judge’s hands now. All we can do is hope. Liz takes Ted’s hand as a melancholy falls over the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Liz walk up to a dog pound.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Are you sure you want to do this now?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: If not now, when? Just because we don’t have our house on the Sound, doesn’t mean we can’t look for the dog... Ted opens the door for Liz.  36 37 30.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. DOG POUND
dialogues.text: Ted and Liz look at DOGS IN CAGES.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (re: a specific dog) What about this guy? He looks like a good roommate. Ted doesn’t respond -- he’s distracted by all these anima in cages. An ominous a reminder of his very possible futu

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Earth to Ted...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: He’s right. This thing should have been a slam dunk. Why couldn’t I just keep my mouth shut?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: If you could do that we never would have met. Her attempt to lighten the mood falls flat. She notices Ted’s hand shaking. She takes it in hers. Knows she needs to be the strong one now.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: No matter what happens, promise you won't leave me, Liz. I don’t know what I'd do without you.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I would never. The BARKING in the background gets louder and more primal He stares them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm, intimate tones. Close, intimate SHOTS: A half-empty bottle of tequila. A salt shaker. Chewed up limes. A turntable playing a LOVE SONG. Ted’s pet plant “FERN.” Ted and Liz fool around -- drunk, giggling, undressing ea other in a romantically playful way. As it starts to get heavy -- he GRABS her by the hair. Sh gasps in exhilaration. It’s hot. Two beautiful people in passionate throes. Ted throws her on the bed. His eyes fix in a primal stare Liz stares back in a hot combination of fear and desire..  38 39 31. As Ted goes in for the kill. INT. TED’S APARTMENT - LATER 38 Ted and Liz catch their breath in twisted sheets, sharing joint, looking like they just got fucked by a tornado.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: “Last Night of Freedom” sex? She shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Restless murmurs die down to eerie silence. Judge Hanson looks out over the courtroom. Ted and Liz make flirty eye from a distance. Last night still on their minds.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HANSON
dialogues.text: After an agonizing weekend pondering the arguments presented in this courtroom, and by the power vested in me as both judge and jury, I hereby find the defendant guilty of aggravated kidnapping beyond a reasonable doubt. Liz's blood runs cold. Her entire world flipped upside do

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE HANSON
dialogues.text: You will be remanded to the Utah State Prison to await sentencing. This court is adjourned. CLACK! A court deputy handcuffs Ted, shell-shocked. Liz moves toward him but another deputy holds her back.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (crying) Ted...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Everything's going to be okay, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Ted, I’m sorry...  32.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Don’t give up on me, Liz. I’m going to fix this. I promise!

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Ted, I’m sorry! She stretches to touch him, but court deputies pull him a WE STAY WITH LIZ... watching her heart and soul ripped aw Crying. Two lovers. Torn apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gates open to a drab, geometric compound coiled in razor wire. 41 INT. PROCESSING - DAY 4l Ted strips for a medical inspection while Jimmy Carter’s victory speech plays on a TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted carries prison-issue bedding and amenities and takes the spartan digs as the door locks behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: (phone-filtered) Is it scary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the phone, Ted tries to shield the sound of an off-scr fight between inmates.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Let’s just say men convicted of crimes against women have a short shelf life in here. Everyone was lined up to see me when I arrived. They made me walk the gauntlet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz sits with a glass of wine, imagining the worst, while Molly plays with rubber shark toys in the tub.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: This whole thing is going to be overturned, Liz. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've already filed an appeal. I’ve been working day and night on it. How’s Molly?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Ask her yourself... Liz brings the phone into the bathroom for Molly.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: How's Jamaica, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (goes with it) Uh, just like the postcards, monkey. What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Playing with sharks. When are you coming home?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Soon as they print more plane tickets, monkey. They ran outta ink! I sure do miss you. Liz takes the phone back and returns to the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Jamaica?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I was caught off guard.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Everything's going to be okay, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I want to come see you.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I was hoping you’d say that. They each find smiles despite the distance. Their connect remains strong as ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted works late into the night annotating reams of legal files. A MAN IN A SUIT approaches. Better dressed than a guard, not as polished as a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: MAN IN A SUIT
dialogues.text: Mind if I join you?  34. Ted offers him a seat. Glimpses a DETECTIVE’S BADGE on hi belt. We’ll learn he’s DETECTIVE MIKE FISHER.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: What’cha up to?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Indexing seven hundred pages of testimony.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: Sounds fun.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Not when it’s about you.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: Ever been to Colorado, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: My lawyer told me not to talk to cops.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: My badge give me away?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: No, your five dollar haircut and complete disregard for my time. What’s your game? I’m kind of busy.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: Did you say seven hundred pages?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: The longest yarn ever spun.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: This is no yarn, pal.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Then why does it all unravel if you pull at any one thread? (rattling it off) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: TED, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was a nonconsensual search, there was nothing in my car you wouldn't also find in your own garage, they showed my picture twice to the accuser before putting me in an unfair lineup next to seven other guys who looked nothing like me, all the evidence is circumstantial, the witness is unreliable, she contradicted herself multiple times, and she’s on record saying she’s only ninety percent certain it was me.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: Ninety percent sounds pretty certain.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: A standard interpretation of “beyond a reasonable doubt” is, “If after a consideration of the evidence, you are ninety-five percent certain that the defendant is guilty, you must acquit, because there is reasonable doubt.” Not even she could have found me guilty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fisher grins. Impressed.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: Sounds like one whale of a tale, Ted, and I’m sure you're going to run the table on them, but all I really want to know is if you ever set foot in your friendly neighbor to the east.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Mister, I’m a full-time law student. I hardly have time to step off campus.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: Is that a no?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I should get back to plotting my escape. Fisher stands. Buttons his jacket.  46 36.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: You were.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Sorry?

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: You were a full-time law student. And for the record, my game is homicide. Catch ya’ soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fisher knocks on the table and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I can give you the number of a good barber. (under breath) Asshole. Ted watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz stares at that framed picture of her and Ted laughing Her work neighbor Jerry discreetly leans over...

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Liz, you have a call on line two. Liz looks at the BLINKING LIGHT on her phone. She picks u Talks in a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: University Medical Division.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hi, Liz, this is Detective Mike Fisher. Do you have a moment?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (beat) What about?

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I think you know what it’s about. Liz turns away from Jerry.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (even quieter) They told me he was cleared.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Who did?  47

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: The Seattle police.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I don’t work in Seattle. I work in Colorado.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, there’s nothing I can help you with.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ms. Kendall, it’s my understanding you've been cooperating with Seattle authorities?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (beat) Please don’t call me anymore. Liz hangs up. Fields a look from Jerry. She returns 37. to that framed picture of her and Ted laughing. Concern sets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted enters in good spirits, all things considered. 47 His chains jangle. His lawyer O’Connell waits, looking seriou

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Give me good news, John. Did the appeal go through?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: I told you not to talk to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: You didn’t tell a homicide detective you’d never been to Colorado?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: The guy with the hair?

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: He had your gas slips. He knew you were lying. He was baiting you. He’s going to extradite you for murder. Like all the air got sucked out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: But I didn’t lie.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: You’ve never been to Colorado?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m an avid skier, John, of course I’ve been to Colorado. Liz and I have been all around Colorado. But I didn’t tell him I have, and I didn’t tell him I haven't. I didn’t tell him anything. He’s putting words in my mouth!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: He’s transferring you to Aspen where the state will establish cause to go to trial.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Since when is it a crime to go to Colorado? JOHN O’CONNELL Since detectives in surrounding states started looking for commonalities in their open cases and finding ways to make you fit.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: John, you have to stop this. They're railroading me!

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: I’m not licensed in Colorado. I can give you names of good counsel, but they’re expensive. Otherwise, they’1l provide you with a public defender. Ted looks like he just got punched in the gut.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: Did you learn nothing from your trial? When you don’t know the angle, you keep your mouth shut.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: How bad is it?  48 49 39.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN O'CONNELL
dialogues.text: They're not saying, but my advice? If you can’t pound on the facts, pound on the table. O'Connell snaps shut his briefcase and gets up. Off Ted, alone. Shell-shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joanna watches Liz pour a double vodka. They keep their voices down because Molly’s sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (re: vodka) Bad day?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Ted’s on his way to Colorado.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Colorado? Liz takes a big gulp.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: It’s about a missing girl, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: It’s a mistake, Jo.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: The news said Seattle PD’s looking at him in connection to those two girls who disappeared from Lake Sam that one summer. Remember that sketch in the paper that looked like him?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: That sketch looked like everyone.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: They're saying he’s on a suspect list.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: There were over thirty thousand names at one point. Every brown- haired guy with a Volkswagen Bug. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a mistake -- the police told me he was cleared -- twice.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: How do you even know that? And why is he in jail? And how did his name get on that list in the first place?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (beat) I think you should leave. Liz downs the rest of her drink. She pours another. Joann watches, concerned by Liz’s behavior, then goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz sits in the shower, crying uncontrollably beneath the stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The corrections van approaches the picturesque Rockies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over an establishing shot...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: These proceedings are a preliminary hearing to rule whether there exists sufficient evidence to require a trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gallery has more people than the Utah trial, includin local reporters and photographers. Ted sits with his new public defender, the young JIM DUMA whose youth and inexperience will make John O’Connell see like a Jedi Master in comparison. (NOTE: Any time Ted is in court he will be in civilian clothes since he is not convicted of anything. He’s got a awesome sweater/turtleneck/bow tie collection. ] District attorney FRANK TUCKER stands before JUDGE LOHR.  53 54 41.

dialogues.speaker: D.A. FRANK TUCKER
dialogues.text: Your Honor, the state of Colorado seeks to prosecute the defendant to the fullest extent of the law for the murder of Caryn Campbell, who disappeared from a well-lit hallway at the Wildwood Inn in Aspen on January 12, 1975. A month later, her nude body was found in a snowbank several miles away. She was killed by blows to her head with a blunt instrument that left distinctive linear grooved depressions on her skull. Therefore, the state would like to enter into record the defendant's most recent conviction in Utah in the attempted abduction of a young woman with a crowbar bearing an unmistakable similarity in shape to the skull fractures found on Ms. Campbell. Ted kicks Dumas under the table -- do something.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DUMAS
dialogues.text: Uh, objection, Your Honor. Dumas stands before he knows what he’s going to say. Ted writes something on a piece of paper for him.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DUMAS
dialogues.text: Uh, your Honor, this is a baseless and desperate ploy to conjoin nonexistent areas of commonality between two separate cases in two separate states.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: (beat) Sustained. Ted breathes a sigh of relief. That was close. A small victory in a bigger ballgame. We hear camera shutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEPUTY WESTERLUND, steps out into the hallway to smoke as pre-trial continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FEMALE WITNESS points off-screen.  42.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE WITNESS
dialogues.text: That’s him, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: Ma’am, are you sure you saw Caryn Campbell in the corridor of the Wildwood Inn with that man?

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE WITNESS
dialogues.text: No doubt in my mind, Your Honor. REVEAL she’s not pointing at Ted, but UNDERSHERIFF BEN MY An ERUPTION OF CAMERA SHUTTERS as murmurs ripple through room. Ted suppresses a smile. There may be hope after all

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz huddles on the phone, looking like hell, nursing a splitting headache. She tries to speak quietly at work.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (filtered) Guess where I am.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, really, guess.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I don’t know, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Not even one guess?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: How the hell should I know? She fields a glance from Jerry. Turns away, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted spins around in a swivel chair.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Well if you’re going to be a spoilsport about it... I’m sitting in the law library of the Aspen Courthouse. Can you hear my chains jangling?  43.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: No, Ted. I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That's because I’m not wearing any! WIDEN TO REVEAL -- Ted at a long, lacquered wooden table, with no restraints. Aside from Deputy Westerlund guarding the door, he’s alone.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I convinced the judge to make me co- counsel which means I have all the privileges of a lawyer. They gave me a typewriter, a desk, trips to the library, and uncensored use of the phone. The other prisoners think I’m some big-wig! Ted watches Westerlund step out into the hall for a smoke Westerlund stays nearby, hitting on a YOUNG WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Can we talk later? I have a headache and I have to work. She hangs up. After a beat, the PHONE RINGS again.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (answering) University Medical Division.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I want to tell you about this book. Have you heard of Papillon?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: A book?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s about a guy wrongfully convicted of a terrible crime and sentenced to life--

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Ted. She hangs up. The PHONE RINGS again. Patience wearing thi

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: What?  57 58

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: He obsesses over the day he’ll be free again, spends years hatching escapes, getting caught, punished, beaten, and betrayed, but he never loses hope. That’s my wish for us, Liz -- that we never lose hope.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (beat) Does he make it out?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m not going to ruin the ending.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (softening) Call me tonight. She hangs up. A small smile lingers.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 57
dialogues.text: INT. LIZ’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 58 Liz is on the phone with Ted. A glass of wine nearby. She absently switches on and off a lamp as they talk: On... off... on... off...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? You seem distant.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Would you still love me if you found out something awful you didn’t know? On... off...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Liz, you're scaring me. Are you sure you’re okay?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I can stand another trial, Ted. It’s too painful to go through again.  59 60 45.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s not a trial, it’s a preliminary hearing to establish cause to go to trial, which won't happen because the evidence is all fabricated and the eyewitness picked out the wrong guy. They’re going to throw this out and send me back to Utah -- which is still under appeal -- where I’1l1 finally show it for what it is -- a witch hunt. Have you bought your plane ticket yet?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (again) I can’t do another trial, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You have to come, Liz. Promise you'll come. (beat) Liz? Promise you'll come! Off Liz, staring. On... off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still waiting on her answer, Ted hears her hang up. Or di they get disconnected? Either way, it worries him.

dialogues.speaker: COURT DEPUTY, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: All rise!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks very distracted. First time he looks anything b confident in court.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: As a pretrial, we're not here to consider the credibility of the evidence, only its existence, therefore this court rules in favor of the defendant standing trial for the murder of Caryn Campbell. HARD SMASH INTO Ted’s horror-stricken incredulity.

dialogues.speaker: D.A. FRANK TUCKER
dialogues.text: Your Honor, the state also seeks a hearing to consider the death penalty should the trial come to that phase.  61 62 63 46.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: We'll determine that at a later date. For now, the defendant shall be held without bail. This court is adjourned. Lohr clacks the gavel. Everyone rises but Ted, who remain in paralytic shock.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Death penalty?

dialogues.speaker: JIM DUMAS
dialogues.text: It’s just a formality. Their case is circumstantial at best and their centerpiece is an eyewitness without very good eyes. It’s a slam dunk.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Funny, my last lawyer said the same thing. As he’s shackled, a gust of wind BLOWS PAPERS off the tab Ted notices BILLOWING CURTAINS at an OPEN WINDOW in the b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted waits on the phone, listening to it ring and ring and ring, but no one picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sits on his top bunk, stewing, staring down at the ha floor, a decision taking shape in his mind...

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION REPORTER, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Ted, you’re a law student standing trial for murder, convicted of an attempted kidnap, yet you adamantly maintain your innocence. You've been in Colorado two months. Does it make you angry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In an on-camera interview, Ted now has a BEARD and OVERGR HAIR. Despite the turmoil of his personal life, he exudes infectious charisma. Smiling, articulate:

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Sure I get angry. I get very, very angry and indignant.  47.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION REPORTER
dialogues.text: But you are not guilty? INTERCUT: Ted jumps off the top bunk in his cell.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Does that include the time I stole a comic book when I was five years old? INTERCUT: Ted jumps off his bunk again.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (laughs ) I am not guilty of the charges which have been filed against me.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION REPORTER
dialogues.text: And the allegations?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: And the allegations. INTERCUT: Ted jumps off his bunk again.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION REPORTER
dialogues.text: And the rumors and innuendo...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (laughs ) I don’t know all of what you’re speaking about, it’s too broad and I can’t get into it in any detail, but I’m satisfied with my blanket statement that I’m innocent. 64 INT. LIZ’S HOUSE - DAY 64 Liz watches TED’S INTERVIEW with a drink in hand.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION REPORTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: You have yet to stand trial and the death penalty is already being discussed.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: I think I stand about as much chance dying in front of a firing squad as you do being killed ina plane flight. Let’s hope you don’t!  65 66 67 68 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted watches his own interview as he gets a shave and cut, making him look very different from the interview footage

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION REPORTER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: You don’t lie awake at night thinking about it?

dialogues.speaker: TED, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Not a moment. INT. TED’'S CELL - NIGHT 66 Ted jumps off his bunk again, sticking a hard landing -- steeling his ankles for impact.

dialogues.speaker: TELEVISION REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Do you think about getting out?

dialogues.speaker: TED'S TV INTERVIEW 67
dialogues.text: A mischievous smile spreads across Ted's bearded face...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (beat) Legally, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted’s now clean shaven, with close-cropped hair, and we g the sense he planned it that way. He’s also oddly bulked heavy layers despite everyone else’s light, summer clothi Just over his shoulder, the CURTAINS of the open window BILLOW in the background. Sweat rolls down his temple. Heat? Or nerves?

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: Does the defense have anything further to add in this pretrial sentencing consideration?

dialogues.speaker: JIM DUMAS
dialogues.text: Your Honor, the death penalty is premised upon blood vengeance. It carries the very real risk that the innocent will be executed. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JIM DUMAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The defense requests that this court exclude the death penalty on the grounds that it is arbitrary and capricious.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: Let’s take a fifteen minute recess before concluding with the prosecution’s final arguments. Lohr bangs the gavel and retires to his chambers. The courtroom empties out.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DUMAS
dialogues.text: Let’s get some air.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m going to stay and practice my final remarks if that’s alright. Dumas exits, leaving Ted alone in the courtroom. Ted thro a friendly smile to Westerlund, standing post at the door The curtains billow at the open window in the back. Ted gets up. Wipes sweat from his temple. His heart thump loudly in his chest. He wanders around the room, pretendi to read a file while stretching his legs. Westerlund finds his pack of smokes and steps into the ha for his regularly scheduled smoke. Once Westerlund exits, Ted climbs onto the sill of the op window. Heart beating out of his chest. Random foot traff below. He steps out onto the ledge -- higher than he expected. He steadies himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a WOMAN waits for her LITTLE DOG to poop on the courth lawn... ...Ted_ jumps out _a second story window, twisting his an upon landing. He gives a smile and a wave to the woman, w watches him briskly limp away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Westerlund flirts with the same YOUNG WOMAN:  70 71 72 73 74 75 50.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY WESTERLUND
dialogues.text: .++.-Sso I unholstered my service weapon, making like I was about to discharge -- that means shoot -- and this punk drops to his knees quicker than Warhol on a naval ship, slides the record across the floor right on up to my boots. You know what it was? Iggy Pop. So I arrested him for bad taste. The WOMAN WITH THE LITTLE DOG and pooper scooper interrup

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN WITH A LITTLE DOG
dialogues.text: Pardon me, but is it common for people to jump out of windows around here? Westerlund looks inside. His cigarette drops from his lip

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sprints down an alleyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Westerlund leaps down stairs, radio mic to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: DEPUTY WESTERLUND
dialogues.text: Code 9! Repeat, Code 9 at the Pitkin County Courthouse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted dashes across traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Westerlund shoves outside, frantically looking everywhere

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted ducks into some foliage. Strips down to blue jean cutoffs and a long-john top. Ties a red bandana around hi head -- completely transforming his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court reconvenes to a heavy din of panic and surprise Dumas looks at Ted’s empty seat:  76 77 78 79 80 51.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DUMAS
dialogues.text: (to himself) That’s the poorest show of faith in this argument I’ve seen yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now looking like a college student, Ted stuffs his excess layers into a pack fashioned out of a turtleneck. Throws over shoulder. Rejoins the sidewalk traffic without a sec glance from anyone -- except those girls who think he’s c Ted gives them a smile, like there’s nothing wrong. As SIRENS erupt in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police cruisers skid across lanes, two at a time, blockin traffic in and out of the city. We hear a HELICOPTER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted races through the woods -- cops, dogs, and helicopter not far off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted scampers up a steep grade trail at a relentless pace, making a getaway into... the MOUNTAINS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz puts away groceries after work. Her phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Turn on the TV.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE of Ted's escape... the daring jump... th stunned courtroom... the buzz around Aspen... roadblocks. tracking dogs... posses on horseback... etc. INT. LIZ’S HOUSE - NIGHT 80 Liz is WATCHING THIS COVERAGE ON TV when -- a sudden KNOC at the door startles her. She sees a MAN’S SILHOUETTE. Could it be? Liz slowly moves toward it. She peeks out at... Colorado Detective Mike Fisher. He shows her his badge.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz pours Fisher coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: Did he give any indication he was planning this? Liz shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: I can’t stress how important it is you notify me if he contacts you. And if you know anything that you're not telling me, you would be guilty of aiding and abetting.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: You came all the way from Colorado just to tell me that? Fisher reveals a large MANILA ENVELOPE marked “CONFIDENTI

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: I thought you should see firsthand just how serious this is. Liz doesn’t take the envelope. Doesn’t want to?

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: If you help us get him, you can prevent it from happening again.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Whatever you think you know about him, it’s all a lie. He didn’t do what you think he did. This is all a mix-up.

dialogues.speaker: DET. MIKE FISHER
dialogues.text: Ma’am, there are things you don’t know, that I can’t tell you right now, that will shock you beyond your worst nightmares, and it’s only a matter of time before the cards are on the table. And when they are, they will wrack you.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (cross—armed) Is that it? Fisher leaves the envelope on the table, gets up, and sho himself out. Liz looks at the envelope but doesn’t open i  82 83 84 53.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. MOUNTAIN CABIN
dialogues.text: Ted snaps awake in a cabin he broke into for the night. H orients himself, then gets up and stretches. A peaceful mountain morning. In the kitchen, he rifles through cupboards. Saltines, ti of Polish bacon, stewed tomatoes -- he shovels it all in. ...until a POLICE HELICOPTER roars overhead. Ted drops to his knees, scurries to the window -- where h hears POLICE and SEARCH DOGS approaching in the distance! Ted scurries back to the far window. He CLIMBS OUT, back- crawling away, then running, but he trips, falls, and-- --looks up INTO THE BARREL OF A SHOTGUN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in custody in the same courtroom he just fled, ARMED DEPUTY SHERIFFS flank Ted as Lohr arraigns him on new charges. The windows are also now locked and guarded.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: ...Two counts felonious escape, one count burglary, one count auto theft, one count misdemeanor theft, the sum of which carry a total of ninety years. I hope it was worth it, son.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (grins) It was just too pretty outside. He gets a chuckle from some in the courtroom. Photographe snap away. He realizes he’s the center of attention now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An establishing shot of the quaint 10-cell “mom and pop” with a PRIVATE RESIDENCE affixed to the end. We hear an ELECTRONIC BUZZ... (PRE-LAP)  85 54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prison door opens. Ted bounds in, running into Liz’s ar both crying tears of happiness.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: Ted and Liz sit as close as two people can, touching and cuddling each other. First time they’ve been together in while. Security is lax in this mom and pop shop.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s a bed and breakfast compared to Utah. The head jailer and his wife live in an apartment attached to the end of the jail. Kinda feels like a vacation if you don’t think about it too much. Ted surprises her with a newspaper-wrapped GIFT.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I didn’t bring you anything.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You brought me the only thing I wanted in the whole world when all I really deserved was a lump of coal. Open it. Liz unwraps newspaper off a well-worn copy of Papillon.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’ve read it four times. You remember what it’s about, right?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: “Never lose hope.”

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You haven't, have you? A melancholy falls over Liz.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I know it’s hard. It’s hard for me too. It was foolish of me to run, but you weren’t answering my calls and I got scared you were going to leave--  55. Ted suddenly realizes, Liz came here to break up with him

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Oh no. Don’t do this, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Your lawyer called. He said the Utah appeal was rejected. A major blow.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I‘1ll take it all the way to the Supreme Court if I have to. Liz, I’ve got documents that will destroy their case.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: They didn’t give you probation. They gave you fifteen years.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That’s a maximum. No one gets the max on a first conviction.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: And now you’re looking at ninety more for running.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I told you, I’m going to straighten everything out.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I can’t do this anymore, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Do you not love me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: No, I do. That’s the problem.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What if I got out? We could run away together. Canada, maybe. I don't understand, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. This is from Molly. She gives him an ENVELOPE and hurries away in tears.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Please don’t do this, Liz!  86 87 88 56. Ted looks like he was hit by a truck. Now he’s all alone. He opens the envelope -- inside is a CRAYON DRAWING OF A SHARK.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 86
dialogues.text: INT. TED’S CELL - NIGHT 87 Ted tapes Molly’s shark drawing on the ceiling so he can at it while he lies in bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparse Christmas decorations adorn the office. Liz looks like hell. She stares vacantly at the copy of Papillon. H desk phone is noticeably silent. She removes the picture of her and Ted from the frame and sticks it in the pages of Papillon, literally closing the book on Ted. She puts the book in a drawer and shuts it.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s your resolution? Jerry unpacks a brown bag snack at the next desk over.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: For the new year. Mine’s to lose two belt notches, except I always manage to find ‘em later.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I don’t really have one.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Everyone’s got something they want, or wanna get rid of.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: What if you don’t know which it is?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: My experience, you probably already know but aren’t ready to admit it. Liz wells up. Not Jerry’s intention.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: But I’m wrong a lot.  89 90 91 92 93 57. INT. TED’S CELL - NIGHT 89 Ted lies on his bunk, still staring at Molly’s shark drawing... as his eyes take focus on something else -- th METAL PLATE in the ceiling holding the light fixture.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dear Liz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted waits on the phone but the other end just keeps ringi He hangs up. Crushed.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There are many things I can live without...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At his print shop job, Ted slices reams of paper, staring off. Losing hope... as we slowly PUSH IN on the BLADE.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...but you’re not one of them. INT. TED’S CELL - DAY 92 Ted extracts the blade hidden under his pant leg in his s Considers its sharpness.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I may have lost you, but I’1l never lose hope. Ted climbs onto his bunk and knocks on the metal plate in ceiling. It’s HOLLOW. He grates the paper cutter blade against it. GROOVES appe INT. JUDGE LOHR’S CHAMBERS - DAY 93 Ted and Dumas meet with Judge Lohr privately. Christmas decorations adorn the court.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: I’ve concluded there’s no way to obtain an unbiased jury in Aspen in light of recent events, so I’m moving you to Colorado Springs where your antics have not been daily news.  94 95 58. Ted stares back at Lohr in sheer panic. His shot at escap now in jeopardy.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I have a good feeling about Aspen. I’d prefer to stay right where I am.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: I’ve ruled and it’s final.

dialogues.speaker: JIM DUMAS
dialogues.text: Ted, this is great news.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE LOHR
dialogues.text: You'll be transferred after the holidays. Merry Christmas. Ted looks anxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over a reminder shot of the “mom and pop” jail with priva residence affixed to the end, we hear URGENT SAWING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the SHOWERS on in the background to mask the noise, double-times it with the paper cutter blade, making quick work of a square foot cutaway in the metal ceiling plate. The showers momentarily shut off. Ted stops sawing. Waits They turn back on and he resumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A square foot of metal POPS FREE. TED’S HANDS reach up in a dark, cobwebbed crawl space and feel around. He hoists himself up, squirming through the narrow hole. Down a ways, a SHAFT OF LIGHT spears up from the floor. H crawls toward it, coughing from the dust, trying to keep quiet on the old wooden paneling. The JAILER and his WIFE are having a marital argument bel

dialogues.speaker: HEAD JAILER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I don’t understand why you’re so teed up?

dialogues.speaker: JAILER'S WIFE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It’s called intimacy, Ed -- ever heard of it? It doesn’t work if you hide things from me.  96 97 98 59.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD JAILER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ever heard of not going to bed angry? Ted SNEEZES. Did they hear him? He keeps perfectly still.

dialogues.speaker: JAILER'S WIFE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: HEAD JAILER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I said goodnight. Ted HEARS A LAMP CLICK OFF. The light through the floor G OUT. He waits IN THE DARK as they fall asleep... INT. HEAD JAILER’S BEDROOM - NIGHT - LATER 96 The HEAD JAILER and his WIFE are sound asleep in the midd of the night. A FINGER emerges from the HOLE in the plasterboard ceilin A panel is carefully removed. TED’S LEGS dangle through t hole, as he eases himself down into their PRIVATE RESIDEN Ted drops down. The jailer and his wife stir but don’t wa Ted tiptoes toward the dresser and carefully opens the drawers. The antique wood squeaks. Ted holds his breath, but the couple still doesn’t wake. Ted sheds his prison garb and puts on the jailer’s warmer clothes. He then climbs a bookshelf next to the sleeping jailer and carefully replaces the ceiling panel, leaving trace of his presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted exits in CIVILIAN CLOTHES out of the PRIVATE RESIDENC affixed to the quaint 10-cell “mom and pop” jail. He hurr off into the cold night as his LETTER VO RESUMES...

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
