dialogues.text: Hope that we’ll meet again, ina big house, with a brick chimney, a view of the Sound, and a rowdy little doggy eager to lick our faces happy again. INT. TED’S CELL - DAY 98 The next day, the HEAD JAILER delivers lunch to Ted’s cel where he finds an untouched breakfast tray. Sees Ted asle under the covers, but not breathing. The jailer enters...  99 60.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Where we’ll make love like we did back when things were serene and uncomplicated, and life was still a dream waiting to be had. The jailer rips back the covers revealing COILED LEGAL PA and LAW TEXTBOOKS in the shape of a body.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Love, ted.

dialogues.speaker: HEAD JAILER
dialogues.text: Son of a...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE of Ted's escape... the square foot cutaw in the ceiling... the dumbfounded cops... the warnings to public to lock their cars and their homes... etc. INT. LIZ’S HOUSE - NIGHT 99 Liz looks out the window. Joanna's with her.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Liz, this is crazy. He’ll never come here. The cops are probably on a round-the-clock stakeout.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: If anyone could do it it’s him.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: What are you going to do? Run away? Live on the lam? He’s a fugitive.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You just had one. Liz starts for the liquor cabinet. Joanna blocks her.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Since when is it a crime to take the edge off every once in a while?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: Since your little girl started asking why her mommy’s so sad. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And it’s more than once in a while so don’t try to soft pedal it and make me out to be the grinch. Everyday’s the same, Liz. You read letters from Ted, you drink, and you cry.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I take care of myself, I have a job, it’s not like I leave my child at home while I run from tavern to tavern. I’m a good mother!

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You’re a great mother. You’re also in denial. What is it about this guy?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: When I feel this love, I feel like I’m on top of the world. When I don’t, I don’t feel anything. (then) What if the only thing he’s guilty of is running a stop sign?

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: He’s been convicted of abduction in Utah, accused of murder in Colorado -- the first time may have been bad luck, but you can’t tell me the second wasn’t a little suspicious. What if there’s a third?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: There isn’t a third.

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: You better hope not, because that would be pretty damn convincing. Liz glares at Joanna, a voice of reason Liz isn’t ready t accept yet. Liz goes around Joanna, pours herself a drink

dialogues.speaker: JOANNA
dialogues.text: (beat) You know this didn’t start with a stop sign.

dialogues.speaker: THE FOUNDATIONS, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Why do you build me up...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 100 101 102 103 104 105 62. ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE of snowy Aspen and the local police “certain” Ted is nearby and won't get far..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of warm, humid, Florida. INT. TED’S ROOM - FLORIDA ROOMING HOUSE - DAY 100 An old LANDLORD shows Ted a shoddily furnished room with paint chipping off the walls. He’s sweating in a rolled u shirt because it’s hot, humid, and sticky here. Ted opens the window, letting in the warm FLORIDA breeze. They shake on a deal to rent. Ted tapes Molly’s dog-eared, well-creased shark drawing t the wall and gets wistful because it’s his only familiari We'll start to notice the song playing over plays a HALF- SLOWER THAN NORMAL. Like the Ramones in the beginning, it a nearly imperceptible warp to an otherwise happy song. Something’s off -- we don’t know it; we feel it.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. PHONEBOOTH
dialogues.text: On his way home with groceries (SORORITY GIRLS pass in th b.g.), Ted stops in a phonebooth, debates calling Liz...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Liz is curled in depression, staring at the ph willing it to ring...

dialogues.speaker: I/E. PHONEBOOTH
dialogues.text: Ted thinks better of calling and hangs up instead. INT. SHERROD’S NIGHTCLUB - NIGHT 104 A pulsing college disco. Ted’s pouring his heart out to EMPATHETIC CO-EDS who really feel his pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted drives, singing along to the song he played for Liz o the jukebox that first fateful night for two young lovers He thumps the steering wheel to the beat, as the song end He tunes the radio through various stations playing music news of the time, during which we’ll catch the words “Chi Omega sorority.” Before we get a chance to hear more-- RED AND BLUE LIGHTS play over Ted’s face.  106 63.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: No... He clocks his rearview. Hears a siren CHIRP.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: No, no, no... Ted cuts a sharp turn -- into a DEAD END. He hits the bre and pounds the steering wheel as the cop boxes him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted steps out of the car, feigning innocence like he did the beginning with Hayward in Utah. OFFICER DAVID LEE, young and husky, steps out of his poli cruiser.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: My apologies, Officer, I couldn't make your car with the headlights in my eyes and I guess I got spooked. A loaded beat as Ted waits to see if Lee buys it. Doesn’t look like it. Ted tries to RUN. Lee GRABS HIM. Wrestles Ted down. They tussle around like a schoolyard fight. The commotion causes nearby homes to turn on their lights ROBED MAN exits his front door, puzzled by the scuffle.

dialogues.speaker: ROBED MAN
dialogues.text: (to Lee) What are you doing to that young man?

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER LEE
dialogues.text: Stay back, sir! Lee flips Ted onto his stomach and drives him into the pavement with his knee. He latches a handcuff, but before gets the other--

dialogues.speaker: ROBED MAN
dialogues.text: Leave him alone or I’m calling the police.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER LEE
dialogues.text: I am the police! --Ted writhes free! He takes off sprinting. Lee draws his gun.  107 64.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER LEE
dialogues.text: Halt! Halt or I’1l shoot! Lee fires a WARNING SHOT. Ted keeps running until he disappears into the shadows. Lee curses and runs after. INT. KITCHEN - LIZ’S HOUSE - NIGHT 107 Liz, Joanna, and Molly are playing Go Fish over dinner. They're all laughing, even Liz. Then the PHONE RINGS. Liz gets a bad feeling. Joanna and Molly keep playing as gets up and slowly makes her way to the ringing phone. Sh afraid to answer. She hesitates, then picks up. She can’t find her voice.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) I’m in Florida. We STAY ON LIZ, only hearing Ted. He sounds down. Deflate His spirit gone.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm in custody. A dagger in Liz's heart.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I made a deal with the police they wouldn’t announce my arrest until I could call you first. They didn’t know who I was. I’ve been playing with them all night. I finally gave them my name for this phone call. A long pause. We hear Ted sniff back tears.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) It’s going to be bad when it breaks, Liz. Real bad. Liz looks at Joanna, who can already tell it’s bad. They both get tears in their eyes. Molly’s luckily too preoccupied to notice.  112 65.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A TAPE RECORDER rolls. Ted’s with three detectives, PATCH CHAPMAN, and BODIFORD, who look like a tough audience. Te has the wear and tear of his scuffle with Lee on his face

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You seriously never heard of me? Don’t you watch the news?

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Right. You jumped out of a window like I won the Super Bowl. The detectives laugh. Ted looks slightly disappointed. Then the door OPENS and Officer Lee (the arresting office enters and lays down an FBI Ten Most Wanted flyer with TE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FACE on it.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER LEE
dialogues.text: Would you sign it for me? This raises a few eyebrows. Proudly:

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Who wants to hear about my second escape?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted’s slumped in a windowless iron cell with a bed and combination sink-and-toilet, admiring Molly’s well-crease shark drawing, which he’s managed to keep. The light’s poor and the humidity makes him sweat. The CELL DOOR UNLOCKS. A man in an expensive suit and haircut enters, picking lint off his sleeve. SHERIFF KEN KATSARIS -- tall, Greek, and handsome.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Are you my lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF KEN KATSARIS
dialogues.text: That’s funny, I thought you were one? Katsaris straightens his cuffs. Ted doesn’t respond. Not sure who this guy is, or what the angle is yet.  108 66.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF KATSARIS
dialogues.text: The game is over, Ted. Your days of walking without the clatter of chains are done. Florida is the Buckle of the Death Belt and it’s my job to tighten things up ina major way.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: A bit excessive for stealing a car, don’t you think? Katsaris smirks like he knows something Ted doesn’t. He s Molly's shark drawing.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That’s a thresher shark. They have tail as long as their whole-- Katsaris RIPS up the drawing.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF KEN KATSARIS
dialogues.text: I’m the sheriff of this town... and I’m the one who’s going to get you. Washington missed you, Utah gave you away, Colorado lost you, I’m going to fry you. Ted's eyes darken. Katsaris turns and walks out. As if on cue, a PAIR OF JAILERS enter and FORCE Ted onto his back. They HOLD HIM DOWN as a DENTIST follows.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (struggling) What are you doing to me? A DENTAL SPECULUM is shoved in Ted’s mouth. His TEETH are photographed with a macro lens. The speculum is RIPPED OU MODELING PASTE farts out of a tube. An IMPRESSION TRAY is shoved in. Ted GAGS under the barbarism... ...as Sheriff Katsaris watches on with a sadistic grin. Welcome to Ted’s new nightmare.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE of the Chi Omega reporting... a chilling crime... no suspects yet... etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tripod video of a SORORITY HOUSE.  109 113 114 67.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The killer struck first at the Chi Omega sorority house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pillow soaked in blood. Spattered sheets.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He clubbed and then strangled to death twenty year old Lisa Levy and twenty one year old Margaret Bowman.

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER HEADLINES
dialogues.text: “Shadow of murderer looms over campus” “Police seek clues in slaying of two FSU sorority women” “Reward is offered” And a NEWSPAPER PHOTO of a terrified sorority girl peerin out a window.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: At least one of them was raped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted rides down in baggy green jail coveralls, handcuffs, leg chains, flanked by armed DEPUTIES. He looks scared an alone. And then it gets worse... ...as the door opens to an unexpected flurry of CROWD CHA and CAMERA FLASHES. A media frenzy. In the midst of it all is Sheriff Katsaris in his impecca suit, crisp shirt, and shit-eating smirk, holding an indictment. He’s making a show of it -- he’s the hero and Ted’s the villain. Realizing the ambush, Ted swallows his disdain, puts on h game face, and LIMPS out of the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now “on” for the cameras, Ted jauntily LIMPS up to Katsar Before Katsaris can get a word in, Ted takes control, continually interrupting:  68.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What do we have here, Ken? lLet’s see. Oh, it’s an indictment! Alright, why don’t you read it to me.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF KATSARIS
dialogues.text: In the name of, and by the authority of the state of Florida--

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You're up for re-election, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF KATSARIS
dialogues.text: You are charged with--

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You told them you were gonna get me. (to the reporters) He said he was gonna get me. (to Katsaris) You got the indictment. That’s all you're gonna get.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF KEN KATSARIS
dialogues.text: Under section 780.04 of Florida statute-— Ted raises his right hand theatrically like an oath for t news cameras. Ted paces and posts cameras.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I'll plead not guilty right now.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF KATSARIS
dialogues.text: You are charged with two counts murder in the first degree in the Chi Omega sorority killings...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (mockingly) My chance to talk to the press. in front of Katsaris -- wallpaper in comparison -- against the wall, jaw set, eyes burning into the Enjoying this, his theatricality completely eclipses Katsaris who drones on in eye-glazing legalese. Ted yanks

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: We've displayed the prisoner now. the indictment out of Katsaris’ hands.  69.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I've been kept in isolation, I’ve been kept away from the press, I’ve been buried by you, you’ve been talking -- it’s my turn now.

dialogues.speaker: SHERIFF KEN KATSARIS
dialogues.text: We got a court order. There won’t be any press interviews.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Sure there won’t. I’m gagged, you're not. The deputies pull Ted back toward the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I will be heard! Ted holds up the indictment and rips it in half.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUE WITH
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE of the sensational Chi Omega coverage... how, while on the run after two escapes, a man wanted for murder in three states may have committed more murders...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted waits on the phone, listening to it ring. It goes unanswered. INT. LIZ’S HOUSE - DAY Liz's phone rings, but she doesn’t answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted hangs up, dejected. Then he gets an idea and dials a different number...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large room arranged like a cafeteria with bolted down tables and chairs. Armed guards all around. Ted limps in, in his usual handcuffs and leg chains. He looks around, smiles when he sees... .+.-CAROLE ANN BOONE, the girl from the Republican fundra who would do “anything” for Ted. Still has that same spar in her eye. Ted limps over and gives her a big hug.  70.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Why are you limping? Did they hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I have a problem with my leg -- I run too fast. He shows her a ghastly-looking orthopedic LEG BRACE that rigid from his left foot to thigh, which he’ll wear anyti he’s outside his cell.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m glad you came.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: I’m glad you called.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Ted and Carole Ann sit closer now. He’s just told her his entire saga.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s all a ploy for the sheriff to score political points in the next election. He’s been chasing his tail for months on this case and suddenly the biggest fish in America swims right into his pond? Who do you think he pins it on? I just autographed my own wanted poster. I’m more popular than Disney World! Carole Ann shakes her head in sympathy, drinking it all u

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: How did this whole thing start?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Someone gave my name to the police years ago in Seattle, one thing led to another, and now I’m in Florida.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: My God, it really is a witch hunt.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I can’t tell if it’s a comedy of errors, or a Kafka novel.  71.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: You must be lonely, so far from home.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: There are worse places to be than Florida, I guess.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: You probably don’t get too many visitors here.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Luckily I make friends easily.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: It would probably feel good to have a familiar face around.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (half-joking) You gonna move to Florida, keep me company?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: (beat) There are worse places to be. They look at each other. Neither wants to say it but it feels like they’ve just come to an implicit agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LIZ breaks a pencil tip. She opens her desk drawer for a sharpener, and freezes when she sees Papillon inside. She lifts the book out. Pages through it. Finds the pictu she stuck inside of her and Ted. Never lose hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted’s new PUBLIC DEFENDERS sit on foldout chairs outside Ted’s cell. They look more like first year associates tha criminal attorneys. Lead counsel is the “elder” DAN DOWD (40s).

dialogues.speaker: DAN DOWD
dialogues.text: This is Ed, Lynn, and Peggy. I’m Dan, I‘1ll be your lead counsel. We're going to make sure you get the best defense taxes can buy.  72.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Is it true they’re putting news cameras in the courtroom?

dialogues.speaker: DAN DOWD
dialogues.text: You'll be the first nationally televised trial in history. If you make it to trial, that is. The state’s offering a deal. If you plead guilty to the murder charges, they've agreed to recommend life sentences instead of the death penalty.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That's a joke, right?

dialogues.speaker: DAN DOWD
dialogues.text: Considering the evidence they have, it’s worth a discussion.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: If you think there’s any chance in hell I’11 plead to these charges, you're out of your fucking mind. The attorneys trade looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Carole Ann hold hands. They've obviously grown cl quickly.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: What do you mean they want you to plead?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: They’re young, they’re inexperienced, only one has ever done a murder trial, and nothing of this magnitude. How are my own attorneys against me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What can you do?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: What if I was like your publicity agent? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I could set the facts straight, make sure your side of the story is heard.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That would actually help a lot because I’m under a gag order. You would do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Ted, I’m staying in Florida.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I would never ask you to do that, Carole Ann.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: You're not asking, I’m insisting. You need me.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: This trial could get pretty rough. You might hear some pretty ugly things.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: It can’t be any worse than what they're already saying on TV. They've taken something wholesome and twisted it sinister. But what do they know?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Obviously not the truth. She gazes into his eyes like she’s falling in love. If it feels a little weird, it should.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE 121
dialogues.text: of the Florida trial ramping up: Media coverage, intervie fanfare, etc. INTERCUT WITH...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lead prosecutor LARRY SIMPSON gives soundbites to the pre

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: This man is a threat to society and I have every intention of removing him completely...  123 124 127 120 74.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted feeds Carole Ann talking points...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carole Ann regurgitates Ted’s words to the press...

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: It’s obvious the media has already convicted him before he’s had his day in court, and to broadcast it to a national audience proves just how big a charade this really is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE of pretty college girls describing why they're so taken by this charming, accused murder... As national media interest grows... as throngs of reporte and broadcast equipment descend in and around the Miami courthouse in an unprecedented manner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE of a MEDIA CIRCUS: News vans from every network, throngs of reporters, live feeds, etc. Cordoned to either side are TED PROTESTORS who want him to fry, an TED SUPPORTERS who are mostly young women. SUPER: Miami, FL. It’s the Super Bowl of court cases. VARIOUS SHOTS of key players as they enter the courthouse alongside the public: Larry Simpson, Ted’s legal team (Ed Lynn, Peggy, Dan), Detectives Patchen, Chapman, and Bodif Sheriff Katsaris, etc...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz lays around reading Papillon, looking like she hasn’t slept or showered in days. The DOORBELL RINGS. It’s Jerry with a takeout bag.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: I brought chicken soup. You haven’t been at work all week so I figured you were sick. + eH  128 129 130 75.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s dead silent in here, where Ted changes out of his pr jumpsuit into a dapper suit and bow tie -- like he’s gett ready for a performance. He makes a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry (alone) portions out the soup into bowls. He notice Papillon and pages through, unaware of its significance. Then PHONE RINGS. Jerry looks, unsure if he should answer

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (from the bathroom) Can you get that? Jerry answers.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: TED 130
dialogues.text: All the color drains from Ted’s face.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (beat) Who is this?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Who is this? Tense silence. Ted looks sick.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You can’t call here anymore. You're killing her. Ted’s not sure what to say. It hurts:

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Will you give her a message for me? Will you tell her... will you tell her I love her? Dead silence. Jerry hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who was that?  131 132 76. Jerry's startled to find Liz there, drying her hair.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: (shrugs ) Just a salesman. Liz holds on him for a beat, like she knows, then lets it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted carries a beer carton of legal files, leading a procession of jailers toward the courtroom door where the OF THE CROWD becomes audible. Like a boxer before a fight Just before entering, he takes a deep breath. Puts on his game face. A jailer opens the door to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .+.a vast, octagonal room paneled with tropical wood, bra rectangles, and suspended light fixtures. If Utah was an empty house, and Colorado was a bigger ballgame, Miami is sold out show. Thirty three JOURNALISTS with press credentials have rese seats. The public fills the hundred-seat gallery. Attractive college girls (the “TED GROUPIES”) have staked the front row. Only the jury box is empty. Ted takes in the enormity. They’re all there for him. He finds Carole Ann in the crowd, who waves and blows a kiss BAILIFF DAVE WATSON, 70s, a white-haired spark plug of a in a crisply starched white shirt and dark pleated trouse bellows over the crowd:

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF WATSON
dialogues.text: Court will come to order! The noise dies down.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF WATSON
dialogues.text: Please rise for the Honorable Justice Cowart! Everyone rises as JUDGE COWART assumes his marble bench. venerable St. Bernard of a man, with great sagging jowls, horn-rimmed glasses, and a proclivity for old Southern sayings.  133 77.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Bless your hearts. Please sit. In regards to the cameras, we're conducting the public's business, and we're going to do it in the sunshine. After all, this is Florida. (to Ted) You look nice, partner.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Thank you, Your Honor. I’m disguised as an attorney today. Laughter softens the mood.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Well, then, let’s put on a show. Ted surveys all the NEWS CAMERAS.

dialogues.speaker: A LIVE BROADCAST 133
dialogues.text: Lead prosecutor Larry Simpson enters the courtroom as if was rehearsed (it was). We PAN with him to a prearranged chalkboard and easel for his opening statement.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, this case is so much more than a double murder. This case is about catching a monster. He clears his throat. Little nervous because it’s a natio broadcast. During his speech, he sorts through ACTUAL EVIDENCE PHOTO BLOW UPS on the easel (we’ll see them better/closer later).

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: In the early morning hours of January 15th, 1978, a young woman arrived home to the Chi Omega sorority house after a date. She heard a thump upstairs. A man ran down, carrying an oak log, and fled. The young woman went upstairs to investigate, where one of her sorority sisters stumbled out of her bedroom, spitting up blood because her face had been smashed. Her roommate’s too. She was sitting on her bed in a daze. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) They were the lucky ones. We SLOWLY start to PUSH IN...

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: In the next room over, another young woman was lying face down in her own blood. Her neck has been twisted at an inhuman angle. Her jaw was broken. She was missing a nipple. Her body had bite marks on it. She was raped and strangled with a pantyhose garotte so tight her neck was constricted to half its size. (long pause) The next girl, we’re still not sure if she died from strangulation or the blow to her head that left a baseball-sized hole her skull. We do know that her underwear was torn off with such force it left a burn mark on her thigh. (longer pause) Then the police received a call about the next incident six blocks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVEAL -- Liz rapt before the TV. Absolutely horrified by what she’s just heard.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, this case is so much more than a double murder. It’s about catching a monster. Innocent, young women were his prey. Savagery was his method. Tragedy will be his legacy. You will be his judge. On screen, Ted betrays no emotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective Norman Chapman is on the witness stand, getting questioned by prosecutor Larry Simpson:  79.

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: When we questioned him about the crimes, he declined to have an attorney present. In fact, he requested it that way.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: He asked not to have counsel?

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: That’s right. Ted leans over to his head counsel, Dan Dowd:

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (whispers ) Object. He’s lying! Dowd holds up his hand to calm Ted.

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: Then he asked we turn off the recorder, that no notes be taken.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: So this was off the record.

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: He thought so.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: The state of Florida allows bugs -- surreptitious recording devices. But it malfunctioned. That’s why that part of the tape cuts out.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: What part is that, Detective?

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: His confession. Ted shoots a look at Dowd who still doesn’t object.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: (to Chapman) What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: (beat) He said he was a vampire.  80.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Objection! Everyone’s surprised. Two half-asleep jurors perk up. Cowart waits on Ted for grounds.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (beat) Narration on the part of the witness, Your Honor. Ted’s own lawyers crack smug smiles at his adorable attem to play lawyer. Until...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Sustained. Even Ted’s surprised. Just the shot of confidence he need

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I also move to have the detective’s entire testimony stricken from the record on the basis that the word “surreptitious” should automatically disqualify anything from masquerading as evidence, given it’s synonymous with secret, stealthy, clandestine, sneaky, sly, furtive, concealed, and hidden. No true evidence should, could, or would, ever be described in such terms. To make no mention of the fact that the most important part of his story is conveniently missing. One might even conclude he’s lying.

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: (to Ted) You confessed that you did it.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Not according to the witness.

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: What witness?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Me.

dialogues.speaker: DET. NORMAN CHAPMAN
dialogues.text: You're the defendant.  136 137 138 81.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: And a defense attorney.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Now I’m confused as a cow on astroturf. A bizarre moment -- Ted’s simultaneously the defendant, defense attorney, and witness.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: Your honor, this is preposterous.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Testimony will be stricken.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: One other thing, Your Honor, while I've got your ear--

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Quit when you're ahead, partner... but I didn't say how far ahead. Bless your heart. A moment between Cowart and Ted. Respect. Ted smiles to himself. His groupies swoon. Carole Ann gives a thumbs up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the phone, Ted listens to it ring... INT. LIZ’S HOUSE - NIGHT 137 .»».as Jerry holds Liz as she dozes off to sleep. We’1l notice he has discreetly DISCONNECTED the phone cord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted hangs up, more than a little on edge. Reveal Carole Ann's there with him, cuddling.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: How do you keep your spirits up, Bunny? Doesn’t it get you down?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m lucky I have things that make happy. That way I never lose hope.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: (with innuendo) I wish I could make you happy in other ways.  139 140 82.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: How much money do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Carole Ann have sex in a prison bathroom. They bo orgasm together. Need a moment to catch their breath.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Wow. What was that?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (beat) “Last Night of Freedom” sex. He’s thinking about Liz, but Carole Ann thinks it’s all a her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stands before Cowart without the jury present.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Your Honor, there is no justification for the treatment I've been receiving. This is a game and I won’t be a party to it. I’m not staying in this kind of Waterloo! There comes a time when I have to say, “Whoa...”

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: If you say “Whoa,” I’m going to have to use spurs.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Since I have been in Dade County--

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Don’t shake your finger at me, young man.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I am strip searched after seeing my attorney--

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Don’t shake your finger at me! Ted tilts his finger toward Dowd at the defense table.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: That’s fine. You can shake it at Mr. Dowd.  83.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: He deserves it more than you do. Since I have been in Dade County, I did not have any choice in the selection of my attorneys, nor have I been asked at any time my opinion about who should be representing me.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: (aghast) Sir, I don’t know of any case where an individual has received the quality and quantity of counsel you have. Who’s minding the store for the public defender I can’t tell you. It’s unheard of. I’ve never seen anything like it in the history of any case I’ve tried in twenty-seven years at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I demand the reins of my own defense!

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: You may have them, sir, but might I also caution that any lawyer who represents himself has a fool for a client. Dowd stands.

dialogues.speaker: DAN DOWD
dialogues.text: Your Honor, this is as good a time as any to raise the issue of my client’s competency. The man’s life is at stake and he’s playing his trial like a circus! Ted makes a fist, turns to Dowd.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (angry) | You want a circus? I’11 make a circus. I’11 rain on your parade, Jack! You’ll see a thunderstorm! Court deputies prepare to spring into action.  141 142 84.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: (angrier, to Ted) This court is going to proceed on schedule without your voluntary interruptions. Do you understand? Ted takes a breath, finds his cool.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Yes, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Then we’re together. Bless your heart. I just hope you stay with us. If you don’t, we’ll miss you.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: And all these people won’t pay their money to come see me. The court chuckles. Ted loves the attention. Dowd’s resentment grows. Ted stares straight into the court came lens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...straight into Liz's eyes, as if they’re somehow connec in this moment. Liz finds a tiny grin. It’s tender. ANGLE ON Jerry, watching it all. He doesn’t like that Ted still has a hold on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted limps in to see... his mother LOUISE, who tears up at sight of her son shackled.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Mom? Louise goes to hug him. Ted finds Carole Ann and his attorneys off to the side and does the math.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: What is this, some kind of ambush?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Of course not, Bunny. But your lawyers have something important to discuss, I thought it would be best to have your family here too. His mother’s voice cracks with heartache:  143 85.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be able to live if I lost you. It would simply break my heart and never be put back together again.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (re: Dowd) Did he put you up to this?

dialogues.speaker: DAN DOWD
dialogues.text: When you consider the evidence they have, combined with pretrial publicity, and all your antics, it’s highly likely they can secure convictions, and because of the nature of the offenses, several death sentences.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m not pleading! The evidence is all fake!

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: They are going to take your life. My first born. My beautiful baby. A mother cannot outlive her son.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Mom, I did not do these things. I want people to know that. I want them to know the truth.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: We’ll know, Bunny. Who else matters? Off Ted, as doom sinks in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted sits among his defense team, bouncing his knee -- loo like he’s about to sell his soul.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: (to Ted) I understand you have a matter you'd like to present to the court? Ted struggles to stand, paralyzed by doom.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Your Honor...  144 86. His mouth runs dry. He takes a sip of water, hand shaking As a decision takes shape...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (machine gun precision) Never have I encountered a man so brazen in coercing his own client into admitting guilt that it makes me wonder if he has the stamina or basic mental acuity to roll up his sleeves and do the hard work. I do not plead, I will not plead, and I demand the resignation of my roundly inept counsel immediately. The courtroom hangs in heavy silence.

dialogues.speaker: DAN DOWD
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I’d like to resign as counsel.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: The counselor’s first words I can agree to.

dialogues.speaker: DAN DOWD
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Muzzle yourselves, counselors!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I'll consider the motion granted.

dialogues.speaker: DAN DOWD
dialogues.text: How’s this for motion? Dowd storms out of the courtroom. The prosecution looks befuddled. Carole Ann and Louise look worried. Ted looks proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted and Carole Ann have sex again, but this time it’s mor utilitarian. Ted climaxes. Carole Ann looks distant, angr and hurt.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Do you still love her?  87.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: wah , (Playing dumb )

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: (realizing) I'm so stupid.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Carole Ann...

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: I’ve only uprooted my entire life for you.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: She’s not here. You are. She abandoned me. And to think I almost married her... You're the one I should marry. She looks at him. Not if he’s serious.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I can already see it. Once I get out, we could get a house on the Sound, maybe a Mercedes in the driveway, maybe a dog? I can hear him barking now, can you hear it?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: I’m allergic to dogs. But that sounds nice. I just wish we didn’t have to wait.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: We don’t.

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: You'll never convince the judge.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Who says I need his permission?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. RICHARD SOUVIRON, handsome, 50s, in a dapper vest-sui and goatee, directs a pointer over an oversized, double- panel, color blowup of TEETH -- Ted’s teeth. He’s the state’s biggest gun and has a flair for the theatrical.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: (indicating on the photos) These are laterals... bicuspids... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: incisors... (to jury) Each individual’s teeth have particular characteristics that make them unique -- alignment, irregularities, chips, size, sharpness... Souviron opens another double-panel (which we don’t see).

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: This is an enlarged photograph of the victim Lisa Levy’s buttocks. (using the pointer) You can see the double bite. The individual bit once, then turned sideways and bit a second time. The top teeth stayed in about the same position, but the lower teeth, biting harder, left two rings.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: Doctor, can you tell us within a reasonable degree of dental certainty whether or not the teeth represented in that photograph are those of the defendant?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: Yes sir. They made the marks. A collective gasp erupts throughout the court.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: No further questions. Cowart bangs the gavel to restore order as Simpson return triumphantly to his seat. Ted gets up to cross-examine.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Dr. Souviron, analyzing bite marks is part art and part science, is it not?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: I think that’s a fair statement.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: And that really depends upon the experience and education of the examiner?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: Yes.  89.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: And your conclusions are really a matter of opinion.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You've got a given set of teeth, or models, and a given area of skin, a thigh or a calf. Is there any way to test whether those teeth will make the same marks over and over?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yes, because I did an experiment just like that. I took models and I went to the morgue and I pressed the models into the buttocks area on different individuals and photographed them. Yes, they can be standardized, and, yes, they do match.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (feigning disbelief) You said cadavers?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: I couldn't find any live volunteers.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: As with any art form, there must be subjective variance.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: If there’s an area of inconsistency, out it goes. But the odds of finding an identical set -- with the wear on the centrals, the chipped lateral incisor, everything identical -- would be astronomical.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: When you say “the odds,” you’re speaking of some kind of probability?  90.

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: A very high degree of probability. It becomes a practical impossibility.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Is it fair to say that odontology is a relatively new forensic science?

dialogues.speaker: DR. SOUVIRON
dialogues.text: No. I don’t think that’s fair at all. Historically, you have a case of Paul Revere doing identifications, you have testimony admitted to the bar in Massachusetts in the late 1800s, and you can find citations for bite mark cases in the legal justice system that go back twenty-five years. So what’s new?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (conceding) No further questions. Ted collapses into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted’s on the witness stand. His own attorney questions hi

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY GOODE
dialogues.text: To the best of your recollection, when did you incur the chip in your tooth?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: In the middle of March 1978.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY GOODE
dialogues.text: Two months after the Chi Omega murders.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I was eating dinner in my cell in the Leon County Jail and I bit down hard and pulled out a white piece of tooth.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Larry Simpson, on cross-examination, looks at Ted askance  gl.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: You don’t know what the Utah dental records look like, do you?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I don’t exactly carry them around in my book bag.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: (cocky) Are you speaking as the witness or the attorney right now? Ted watches Simpson, wondering what his game is.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Ted as defense attorney approaches the witness, Carole An

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Ms. Boone, did you ever visit me in the Garfield County Jail in 1977?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: And to the best of your memory, did I have any kind of a chip in my front tooth at that time?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: No, you did not. They hold each other’s gaze for a beat before Ted returns his showmanship.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Your Honor, I think you understand what I’m getting at. I’d like to subpoena all newspapers to turn over their negatives of me. If the chip did not occur until March 1978, two months after the Chi Omega crimes, and the state’s odontologists say otherwise, then the state’s odontologists have obviously taken my teeth and twisted them every which way but loose to fit.  92.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: Sir, you may jump up and down and hang from the chandelier, but the court will not dash for new evidence at your command.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (under breath) Lazy prick...

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: You impress me not, sir.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: The feeling is mutual, Your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: I’m sure it is, bless your heart. Unless there is anything else, Ms. Boone may be excused.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: There is one more matter, Your Honor. Ted and Carole Ann smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Will you marry me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROLE ANN
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Then I do hereby marry you. The court freezes in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: (beat) Are you shitting me? Objection.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Your Honor, public declaration, properly phrased, in an open courtroom, in the presence of court officers, constitutes a lawful marriage in the state of Florida. Cowart shrugs at the incredulous Simpson. The newlyweds gleam. Then -- the image CUTS OUT like a TV shutting off.  93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry has just turned off the TV. Liz sends him a vicious look.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You need to let him go. He is slowly killing you and you don’t even realize it.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: You're just jealous Ted and I have a bond that you and I never could. I know you unplug the phones when I fall asleep. Was it him that called the other day? Jerry doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: He froze up because he knows I know he’s a weasel. He is going to fry, Liz, and if you ask me, that’s the easy way out compared to the slow, protracted destruction you're putting yourself through by holding onto him like this. He is killing you, because you’re letting him.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Get out. Jerry doesn’t move.

dialogues.speaker: GET OUT
dialogues.text: Liz slaps Jerry who stands his ground. Instead of leaving Jerry steps toward her.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: You need to let him go, Lizzy.  94.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (breaking down) I just want this all to be over. I wish I could take it all back.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY
dialogues.text: Take what back? Why do you act like you're personally responsible for everything that’s happening to him? PUSHING IN on Liz...

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (long beat) Because I’m the one who gave his name to the police. That’s what started this entire nightmare. OVER, we HEAR/SEE THE OPENING POLICE CALL -- but now we a get the other side of the conversation...

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: King County Sheriff's Department.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Yes, my name is Elizabeth Kendall. I’m calling to report someone who matches the description of the guy from Lake Sam who was seen with those girls who disappeared... Liz was the one who gave Ted’s name to the police.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Is he ever going to find out it was me who called?

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: No, he won’t find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Larry Simpson delivers his closing statement, again wi his easel, this time we SEE IN DETAIL THE ACTUAL EVIDENCE BLOW UPS...

dialogues.speaker: -- BUTTOCKS BITE MARK PHOTO
dialogues.text: -- MACRO CLOSEUP OF TED’S GHASTLY TEETH  155 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- “HOLE-IN-THE-HEAD” PHOTO

dialogues.speaker: LARRY SIMPSON
dialogues.text: ...-He may ask for mercy. His mother may ask for mercy. But how nice it would have been if Lisa Levy’s and Margaret Bowman’s mothers could have been there that morning of January 15, 1978 and asked for mercy for them.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT
dialogues.text: Now Ted delivers his closing statement...

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the prosecution opened this trial by arguing this case is about more than murder. I'd like to close it by making that same argument. There are two ways for the police to investigate a crime. They can go to a crime scene, look for clues, and follow those clues to their logical conclusions. Or, they can begin with a suspect, decide on a suspect, and work to make the evidence fit only that suspect. Two jurors, FLOY and BERNEST, actually drowse in their se

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: This is about more than murder. This is about truth. You can’t judge a man until you know the whole truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz breaks down in Jerry’s arms, collapsing into a rock- bottom mess. Jerry gently rocks her as she cries. We thought we saw love in the beginning with Ted but it w an illusion. THIS is what love looks like.  149 150 151

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted waits with reporters. Carole Ann by his side. Contrasted against Liz and Jerry, Ted and Carole Ann's relationship feels hollow, an artifice.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: Is it just being in the wrong place at the wrong time, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s just being me in any place, I guess. One set of circumstances seemed to bootstrap another, and once you get people thinking in that vein, police officers, they want to solve crimes, and sometimes they don’t really think things through. They’re willing to take the convenient alternative. The convenient alternative is me. Bailiff Watson arrives:

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF WATSON
dialogues.text: The jury has reached a verdict.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Seven hours. Bless their hearts.
149 150 The jury files in. The foreman passes the verdict to Judg Cowart who passes it to COURT CLERK SHIRLEY LEWIS. Ted stands.

dialogues.speaker: COURT CLERK LEWIS
dialogues.text: We the jury, in Miami-Dade County, Florida, find the defendant, Theodore Robert Bundy... ..+.as we PUSH IN on the lawyers, the groupies, the press -..on Louise. +-.on Carole Ann.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 151 ...-Liz and Jerry, now watching together. He's her suppor  97.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...CLOSER ON Ted, alone, betraying no emotion.

dialogues.speaker: COURT CLERK LEWIS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: ---guilty as charged. ...-Larry Simpson pumps his fist. He won. 153 INT. LIZ’S HOUSE - DAY 153 ...-Liz’s soul dies behind her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SOUND DROPS OUT, except for Judge Cowart’s voice, whi sounds as clinically detached as the narration of an old public service announcement.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: It is this court’s reasoned judgment that you be adjudicated guilty of murder in the first degree; that the killings were indeed atrocious and cruel, in that they were extremely wicked, shockingly evil, vile, and with utter indifference to human life; and that you shall be put to death by a current of electricity that shall pass through your body until you are dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now in the penalty phase of the trial, Ted listens to his mother break down on the witness stand.

dialogues.speaker: LOUISE
dialogues.text: I consider the death penalty to be the most primitive, barbaric thing that one human can impose on another. My Christian upbringing tells me that to take another’s life under any circumstance is wrong, and I don’t believe the state of Florida is above the laws of God.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: (tenderly) Now, now, mother. We haven’t lost a mother yet.  Ted chokes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz stands in an AA MEETING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ted stands before Judge Cowart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trembling. Scared:

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: My name is Elizabeth Kendall, and I’m an alcoholic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shaky. Tearful. Like a son facing his father:

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m not asking for mercy. I find it absurd to ask for mercy for something I did not do. I’m not the one responsible for these horrific acts. Although the verdict found in part that those crimes had been committed, it erred in finding who committed them. As a consequence, I cannot accept the sentence, because it is not a sentence of me, it is a sentence of someone else who is not standing here today.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: The court is going to sentence the person found guilty of the offense. Your name, sir, was on the verdict. Carole Ann struggles to restrain her own revulsion.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART
dialogues.text: (genuinely) Take care of yourself, young man. I say that to you sincerely. You're a bright young man. You’d have made a good lawyer, and I’'da loved to have you practice in front of me. But you went another way, partner. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE COWART, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s a tragedy to see such a total waste of humanity that I’ve experienced in this courtroom. I don’t have any animosity toward you. I want you to know that. Take care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Thank you. Cowart anti-climactically taps the gavel. Ted looks into gallery in time to see Carole Ann running out without loo back. He’s now completely alone. As he’s shackled and taken away, the CAMERA FINDS -- etch into the wood of the defense table where Ted’s seat was, SILHOUETTE OF A SHARK. CUT TO BLACK. We think it’s over, until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The office is now more modernized. Other women work here now, and there’s a different face at Liz’s old desk. SUPER: 1989. Nine Years Later. After a beat, LIZ, now in her 40s, exits an office marked “DIRECTOR.” She’s several years sober and further along i her life. She watches the office work. Proud of how far she’s come. A young woman arrives -- Liz’s very own SECRETARY:

dialogues.speaker: LIZ'S SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Kendall? This came for you.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (smiles) Thank you, Janet. Liz feels a jolt when she sees the return address is from FLORIDA STATE PRISON. She considers it the same way an alcoholic considers a drink after nine years of sobriety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz puts the unopened letter in her desk drawer and shuts But we can tell it’s the only thing on her mind.  161 100.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later, with her coworkers gone for the evening, Liz shuts door. She takes the letter out from her desk, opens it, a reads it alone...

dialogues.speaker: TED, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Dear Liz. This will be my last letter. If anyone deserves to hear it as it was -- it’s you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Off Liz, yet to look away...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE of the usual mix of protesters and supporters lined up outside the prison with signs and t- shirts... the circus is still strong nine years later...

dialogues.speaker: NEWS REPORTER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ..+.convicted murderer Ted Bundy is set to die tomorrow in the electric chair unless the Florida Supreme Court grants him a fourth stay of execution...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz waits, nervously bouncing her leg. A metal door OPENS Liz steels herself. This is the hardest thing Liz has eve had to do. SEPARATED BY GLASS... guards usher in Ted, now 42, thinne gaunt, lacking the sturdy frame of his youth. Pale from n years behind bars. By now he’s gotten used to the LEG BRA and CHAINS as he moves. He stops dead when he sees Liz. He sits across from her. Picks up the phone. She hesitate then picks up hers. A long beat of silence. Neither know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (beat) Never lose hope. Ted notices Liz’s wedding ring. Tries to hide the sting w a smile. His smile -- which doesn’t have the same power anymore. It’s dimmer. Weaker.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I didn’t come to catch up, Ted. I came because I need to hear the truth.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s all there in the letters.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: The whole truth.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: There is no truth, only controversy.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: There are detectives from seven states out there, lined up with armloads of open case files.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It’s never going to stop, is it?

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: It will stop with the truth. You can stop it.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I didn’t do anything, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (re: detectives outside) You're telling them that you did. That's what you’re doing, right? Trading the truth to buy more time?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I’m telling them what they want to hear because it’s the only way to save my life. I haven't been convicted of anything except this Florida thing -- which I’m still appealing -- but they’re going to fry me tomorrow if I don’t give them something. I have no choice.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Do you remember the night we met?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You made heart valves.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: You told me you were a lawyer. We started with a lie, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: My love was never a lie. I fell in love the moment I saw you.  102.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I need to hear the truth now.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You know I’m not capable of these things, Liz. I would never hurt a woman. Have I ever laid a hand on you? Have I ever even raised my voice? Remember when we went shopping for ski racks and that lady got her purse snatched--

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I’m the one who gave your name to the police. Ted lets it sink in.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: It was 1974. They put that sketch in the paper of the man at Lake Sam who used a fake cast to lure two girls into helping him mount a sailboat onto a ski rack on his Volkswagen Bug. A ski rack that I lent you.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I remember that sketch. Everyone teased me about the resemblance. We used to laugh about it together.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Part of me never believed you were capable of these things. Part of me still doesn’t. For years, I've carried this horrible guilt that I’m to blame for everything. I used to think I ruined your life, but now I realize you almost ruined mine. What if I could have saved some of those girls? I can’t live like this anymore, Ted. It’s not my guilt. It’s yours. You’re the only one who can release me. A long beat. You could hear a pin drop. Ted’s unreadable.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Did you do these things, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Of course not.  103.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Denise Naslund and Janice Ott, the two girls from Lake Sam?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Carol DaRonch, the girl from Utah, who was too scared to even look at you in court?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: The Colorado girls?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Oh, Liz, you've always been insatiable. You’ve obviously come with an agenda and I’m sorry I can’t give you what you want.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: The sorority girls in Florida?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Absolutely not.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Kimberly Leach? She was twelve, Ted... TWELVE! Ted suddenly POUNDS the table. A flash of anger.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I did not do these things, Liz.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (long beat) Did you ever want to do that to me? A long, heavy silence.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I wish we could be alone... and talk about things... with nobody listening...  104.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (beat) Ted, are you telling me... that you're sick?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (barks ) Back off! First time we’ve seen him unhinged. First time Liz is in control.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: I told you the truth, now you need to do the same for me. Ted stares at her. Nostrils flaring. She’s not letting up

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (desperate) I've been suffocating for nine years, Ted. Nine years I’ve had your hands around my neck. You are killing me, Ted. You need to release me.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Not you, Liz. Anyone but you. Liz pulls out a MANILA ENVELOPE marked “CONFIDENTIAL” -- one Detective Fisher left at her house all those years ag From it, she withdraws a 9x11 PHOTOGRAPH and PRESSES IT AGAINST THE GLASS in front of Ted. We don’t see the photo, we just see Ted fixed on it. His carotid artery pulses fast in his neck. His jaw protrudes. His eyes fix in a lock-stare that looks almost inhuman, like he’s just been transported to whatever scen he’s seeing. And it’s absolutely fucking terrifying.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (beat) What happened to her head? As if broken from deep reverie, Ted looks up -- pupils sh to pinholes, like he’s receded into a distant tunnel in t back of his head.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (slightly disoriented) Um, if she was deposited in the woods, animals could have conceivably--  105.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: Animals don’t do that. Ted starts to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Don’t make me say it, Liz. I’m not a bad guy.

dialogues.speaker: LIZ
dialogues.text: (beat) You need to release me. Room tone LOUDER THAN THUNDER... After an unbearably long beat, Ted lifts his finger as if TOUCH the photo, but then we hear the SQUEAK of his finge glass and realize HE’S WRITING SOMETHING over the photo.. Once he finishes, Liz looks terrified to remove the photo reveal it. Before she does... ECU on TED’S SIGNATURE BLUE EYES, as we ZOOM THROUGH A

dialogues.speaker: DIFFERENT FEEL TO THEM IN THIS NEW CONTEXT...
dialogues.text: -- Ted barking in Liz's ear on their first date... -- The burglary tools we didn't see: ski mask... crowbar. ice pick... -- Ted slinging Molly over his shoulder... -- Ted pretending to bite Liz's nose at the fundraiser... -- Liz smelling Ted's clothes in his luggage... -- Ted under the covers with a flashlight peeping at Liz' naked body as she sleeps... -- Ted “hunting” Liz as their foreplay... -- Ted clamping his hand around Liz's neck in sex...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Ted's anger in pounding the table... -- Ted's EYES -- no longer sweet and blue, but black and scary

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 162 163 106. The cuts come so fast it’s nauseating. Realizing this evi has been in front of us -- seducing us -- the entire time It’s not that we didn’t see it, it’s that we didn’t want Like Liz, like his victims, like everyone he encountered, were inexplicably mesmerized by Ted. We wanted to believe him because we liked h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that we know the truth -- the whole truth -- and noth but the truth -- we feel disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE DUST OF THE WINDOW AS LIZ REMOVES THE PHOTO...
dialogues.text: hacksaw The “K"” is written backwards. Liz SKIDS up out of her chair, gasping in revulsion. Eyes filled with shock, awe, horror... backing far, far away.. Ted keeps his eyes downcast. Face pale. Can’t bring himse to look Liz directly in the eye and makes no effort to explain. He is, in this precise moment, lost to her. WE STAY WITH LIZ, retreating from her former lover, a complete and monstrous stranger now. She BANGS on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liz hurries through security checkpoints, tears streaming past a LONG LINE OF DETECTIVES -- there’s Mike Fisher, No Chapman, Kathy McChesney, etc. -- all with arm loads of C FILES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .--into the claustrophobic humidity where she finally let free a maelstrom of emotion released in an instant. It’s not sadness or shock. It’s a great burden leaving he guilt -- insecurity -- self-loathing -- codependency -- Ted. And there waiting for her, next to a cheap rental car... JERRY and TEENAGE MOLLY. They wrap their arms around Liz her journey is now complete.  107.

dialogues.speaker: TEENAGE MOLLY
dialogues.text: I’m proud of you, Mom. Together, they get into a RENTAL CAR and drive onto a deserted highway that cuts through the vast wasteland tha Starke, Florida... driving away from the prison... moving forward.... starting new... feeling strong. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: Ted Bundy was executed on January 24, 1989. Days before h execution, he confessed to 30 murders. He is suspected of Many more. Most of his victims have never been found. He was cremated and scattered in the Cascades... one of t resting spots of many of his victims. Liz still lives in Washington with her family. She is sob Carole Ann gave birth to a girl fathered by Ted while on death row. Their whereabouts are unknown.
